evidence.text: Job Corps, established by Congress in 1964, is the nation's largest residential employment and workforce development program for youth. It trains and educates young people, 16 to 24 years old, from disadvantaged backgrounds, including individuals who dropped out of school; who are homeless; who are in, or have aged out of, the foster care system; and who require additional career and technical instruction to obtain and retain employment.

extracted.value: Job Corps established by Congress in 1964 as largest residential career training program for disadvantaged youth (16-24 years old) facing barriers like homelessness, foster care, or lack of high school diploma. Provides career technical training, residential services, meals, health care, and counseling. Currently serves ~25,000 students across 25+ centers.

evidence.text: Since March 2025, DOL has taken a series of actions to shut down Job Corps. For example, DOL halted applicant background checks... On April 11, 2025, DOL discontinued dedicated student Career Transition Readiness programs... On April 23, 2025, all pending or outstanding Job Corps procurements except for three were abruptly canceled. On April 25, 2025, DOL released a 'Job Corps Transparency Report'... On April 30, 2025, DOL effectively terminated its provision of internet service to Job Corps campuses. On May 29, 2025, DOL had a call with all Job Corps operators to announce its plan to implement stop work orders on all Job Corps contracts nationwide.

extracted.value: DOL initiated program elimination starting March 2025: halted background checks (preventing new enrollment), discontinued Career Transition Readiness programs (April 11), canceled procurements (April 23), released flawed Transparency Report (April 25), terminated internet service (April 30), and announced nationwide shutdown via termination notices (May 29).

evidence.text: Approximately 20.6% of Adams' active Job Corps student population would be homeless without the program. ... 'I finally feel like I belong somewhere. The program gave me more than an education. It gave me stability. It gave me peace. It gave me purpose. I now feel safe, supported and seen.' She adds: 'If the center closes, I'll have nowhere to go. No money. No plan. No home. I will be scared for my safety. It makes me feel alone again. This place is the only place where I've ever felt safe and grounded. It's the only reason I have hope.'

extracted.value: Students face forced displacement: 20.6% of Adams' students would be homeless without Job Corps; one student states 'I finally feel like I belong somewhere... If the center closes, I'll have nowhere to go.'

evidence.text: Adams... its Job Corps operations make up more than 97% of its revenue. ... Plaintiff ETR began operating Job Corps centers as a small business over 28 years ago and has since grown to be one of the largest operators... Plaintiff NJCA's entire mission is to represent participants in the Job Corps program, and it is dependent almost exclusively on member dues to fund its operations.

extracted.value: Operators face business destruction: Adams (1,900 employees, 97% revenue from Job Corps), ETR (28+ years, $155M annual community impact), and NJCA (entire mission dependent on Job Corps) will cease operations due to abrupt termination.

evidence.text: Congress created Jobs Corps in the Economic Opportunity Act ('EOA') of 1964... In 2014, the Workplace Innovation and Opportunity Act ('WIOA') stated that: 'There shall be within the Department of Labor a Job Corps.' ... Congress contemplated that DOL could close individual Job Corps centers, but did not provide authorization for DOL to cancel the program wholesale. And Congress has imposed specific guardrails on the closure of any individual Job Corps campus. ... Defendants' decision to shut down all privately operated Job Corps campuses exceeds Defendants' statutory authority.

extracted.value: Congressional authorization: Job Corps created by Economic Opportunity Act (1964) and reaffirmed by WIOA (2014) which states 'There shall be within the Department of Labor a Job Corps.' DOL lacked statutory authority to terminate program wholesale without Federal Register notice or 30-day comment period.
